articles.title: SignalWire Releases Open Source SDK for Voice AI
articles.description: SignalWire, the leader in Programmable Unified Communications (PUC), today announced the open beta of its fully open source Call Fabric SDK and Reference App. This milestone release empowers developers to quickly build, customize, and launch modern communications apps, including intelligent solutions powered by the SignalWire Voice AI Agent across web,... articles.title: Gate-level emulation of an Intel 4004 in 4004 bytes of C
articles.description: A feature-complete gate-level microcoded Intel 4004 in 4004 bytes of C, capable of emulating the original Busicom calculator ROM for which the chip was originally designed.
articles.content: A feature-complete gate-level microcoded Intel 4004 in 4004 bytes of C, capable of emulating the original Busicom calculator ROM for which the chip was originally designed.

articles.title: New Report: The Architectural Patterns of Financial AI
articles.description: At Bankwell Bank, a new employee named Sarah works around the clock. She responds to loan applicants via email and SMS in under three minutes, gathers missing documents, and hands a perfectly structured file to her human colleagues. She has re-activated roughly half of the bank’s otherwise lost applicants and saved loan officers 90% ofContinue reading "New Report: The Architectural Patterns of Financial AI" The post New Report: The Architectural Patterns of Financial AI appeared first on...
articles.author: Ben Lorica
articles.content: At Bankwell Bank, a new employee named Sarah works around the clock. She responds to loan applicants via email and SMS in under three minutes, gathers missing documents, and hands a perfectly structured file to her human colleagues. She has re-activated roughly half of the bank’s otherwise lost applicants and saved loan officers 90% ofContinue reading "New Report: The Architectural Patterns of Financial AI" The post New Report: The Architectural Patterns of Financial AI appeared first on...

articles.title: Fighting Style Collapse: Reinforcement Learning with Bit-LoRA for LLM Style Personalization
articles.description: Reward dropout and Bit-LoRA regularization effects.AbstractHere I introduce and experiment with a novel reinforcement learning-based framework for LLM style personalization that uniquely addresses the challenge of style collapse. Unlike existing few-shot prompting methods, this approach ensures both high style fidelity and remarkable diversity, critically requiring only minimal data. Central is a novel style reward dropout mechanism, seamlessly integrated with continuous style similarity...
articles.author: Roman S
articles.content: Reward dropout and Bit-LoRA regularization effects.AbstractHere I introduce and experiment with a novel reinforcement learning-based framework for LLM style personalization that uniquely addresses the challenge of style collapse. Unlike existing few-shot prompting methods, this approach ensures both high style fidelity and remarkable diversity, critically requiring only minimal data. Central is a novel style reward dropout mechanism, seamlessly integrated with continuous style similarity...

articles.title: In-Context Reinforcement Learning via Communicative World Models
articles.description: arXiv:2508.06659v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Reinforcement learning (RL) agents often struggle to generalize to new tasks and contexts without updating their parameters, mainly because their learned representations and policies are overfit to the specifics of their training environments. To boost agents' in-context RL (ICRL) ability, this work formulates ICRL as a two-agent emergent communication problem and introduces CORAL (Communicative Representation for Adaptive RL), a framework that...
articles.author: Fernando Martinez-Lopez, Tao Li, Yingdong Lu, Juntao Chen
articles.content: arXiv:2508.06659v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Reinforcement learning (RL) agents often struggle to generalize to new tasks and contexts without updating their parameters, mainly because their learned representations and policies are overfit to the specifics of their training environments. articles.description: How new laws that keep children safe on the internet work.

articles.title: gpt-oss-120b & gpt-oss-20b Model Card
articles.description: We introduce gpt-oss-120b and gpt-oss-20b, two open-weight reasoning models available under the Apache 2.0 license and our gpt-oss usage policy.
articles.content: We introduce gpt-oss-120b and gpt-oss-20b, two open-weight reasoning models available under the Apache 2.0 license and our gpt-oss usage policy.

articles.title: Figma uses AI to transform digital design
articles.description: Discover how Figma is transforming digital design with AI. David Kossnick shares how tools like Figma Make empower teams to prototype, collaborate, and build with AI—reshaping workflows for designers, developers, and non-technical creators alike.
articles.content: Discover how Figma is transforming digital design with AI. David Kossnick shares how tools like Figma Make empower teams to prototype, collaborate, and build with AI—reshaping workflows for designers, developers, and non-technical creators alike.

articles.title: Elastic Stack 9.1.1 released
articles.description: Version 9.1.1 of the Elastic Stack was released today. We recommend you upgrade to this latest version. We recommend 9.1.1 over the previous versions 9.1.0 For details of the issues that have been fixed and a full list of changes for each product in this version, please refer to the release notes.

articles.title: GFlowNets for Learning Better Drug-Drug Interaction Representations
articles.description: arXiv:2508.06576v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Drug-drug interactions pose a significant challenge in clinical pharmacology, with severe class imbalance among interaction types limiting the effectiveness of predictive models. Common interactions dominate datasets, while rare but critical interactions remain underrepresented, leading to poor model performance on infrequent cases. Existing methods often treat DDI prediction as a binary problem, ignoring class-specific nuances and exacerbating...
articles.author: Azmine Toushik Wasi
articles.content: arXiv:2508.06576v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Drug-drug interactions pose a significant challenge in clinical pharmacology, with severe class imbalance among interaction types limiting the effectiveness of predictive models. Common interactions dominate datasets, while rare but critical interactions remain underrepresented, leading to poor model performance on infrequent cases. Existing methods often treat DDI prediction as a binary problem, ignoring class-specific nuances and exacerbating...

articles.title: Deep Ignorance: Filtering Pretraining Data Builds Tamper-Resistant Safeguards into Open-Weight LLMs
articles.description: arXiv:2508.06601v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Open-weight AI systems offer unique benefits, including enhanced transparency, open research, and decentralized access. However, they are vulnerable to tampering attacks which can efficiently elicit harmful behaviors by modifying weights or activations. Currently, there is not yet a robust science of open-weight model risk management. Existing safety fine-tuning methods and other post-training techniques have struggled to make LLMs resistant to...
articles.author: Kyle O'Brien, Stephen Casper, Quentin Anthony, Tomek Korbak, Robert Kirk, Xander Davies, Ishan Mishra, Geoffrey Irving, Yarin Gal, Stella Biderman

articles.title: A Federated Learning Framework for Handling Subtype Confounding and Heterogeneity in Large-Scale Neuroimaging Diagnosis
articles.description: arXiv:2508.06589v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Computer-aided diagnosis (CAD) systems play a crucial role in analyzing neuroimaging data for neurological and psychiatric disorders. However, small-sample studies suffer from low reproducibility, while large-scale datasets introduce confounding heterogeneity due to multiple disease subtypes being labeled under a single category. To address these challenges, we propose a novel federated learning framework tailored for neuroimaging CAD systems. Our...
articles.author: Xinglin Zhao, Yanwen Wang, Xiaobo Liu, Yanrong Hao, Rui Cao, Xin Wen
articles.content: arXiv:2508.06589v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Computer-aided diagnosis (CAD) systems play a crucial role in analyzing neuroimaging data for neurological and psychiatric disorders. However, small-sample studies suffer from low reproducibility, while large-scale datasets introduce confounding heterogeneity due to multiple disease subtypes being labeled under a single category. To address these challenges, we propose a novel federated learning framework tailored for neuroimaging CAD systems. Our...

articles.title: Segmented Confidence Sequences and Multi-Scale Adaptive Confidence Segments for Anomaly Detection in Nonstationary Time Series
articles.description: arXiv:2508.06638v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: As time series data become increasingly prevalent in domains such as manufacturing, IT, and infrastructure monitoring, anomaly detection must adapt to nonstationary environments where statistical properties shift over time. Traditional static thresholds are easily rendered obsolete by regime shifts, concept drift, or multi-scale changes. To address these challenges, we introduce and empirically evaluate two novel adaptive thresholding frameworks:...
articles.author: Muyan Anna Li, Aditi Gautam
articles.content: arXiv:2508.06638v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: As time series data become increasingly prevalent in domains such as manufacturing, IT, and infrastructure monitoring, anomaly detection must adapt to nonstationary environments where statistical properties shift over time. Traditional static thresholds are easily rendered obsolete by regime shifts, concept drift, or multi-scale changes. To address these challenges, we introduce and empirically evaluate two novel adaptive thresholding frameworks:...

articles.title: Generalizing Scaling Laws for Dense and Sparse Large Language Models
articles.description: arXiv:2508.06617v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Over the past few years, the size of language models has grown exponentially, as has the computational cost to train these large models. This rapid growth has motivated researchers to develop new techniques aimed at enhancing the efficiency of the training process. Despite these advancements, optimally predicting the model size or allocating optimal resources remains a challenge. Several efforts have addressed the challenge by proposing different...
articles.author: Md Arafat Hossain, Xingfu Wu, Valerie Taylor, Ali Jannesari
articles.content: arXiv:2508.06617v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Over the past few years, the size of language models has grown exponentially, as has the computational cost to train these large models. This rapid growth has motivated researchers to develop new techniques aimed at enhancing the efficiency of the training process. Despite these advancements, optimally predicting the model size or allocating optimal resources remains a challenge. Several efforts have addressed the challenge by proposing different...

articles.title: Large Language Models Facilitate Vision Reflection in Image Classification
articles.description: arXiv:2508.06525v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: This paper presents several novel findings on the explainability of vision reflection in large multimodal models (LMMs). First, we show that prompting an LMM to verify the prediction of a specialized vision model can improve recognition accuracy, even on benchmarks like ImageNet, despite prior evidence that LMMs typically underperform dedicated vision encoders. Second, we analyze the internal behavior of vision reflection and find that the...
articles.author: Guoyuan An, JaeYoon Kim, SungEui Yoon
articles.content: arXiv:2508.06525v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: This paper presents several novel findings on the explainability of vision reflection in large multimodal models (LMMs). First, we show that prompting an LMM to verify the prediction of a specialized vision model can improve recognition accuracy, even on benchmarks like ImageNet, despite prior evidence that LMMs typically underperform dedicated vision encoders. Second, we analyze the internal behavior of vision reflection and find that the...

articles.title: MILD: Multi-Layer Diffusion Strategy for Complex and Precise Multi-IP Aware Human Erasing
articles.description: arXiv:2508.06543v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Recent years have witnessed the success of diffusion models in image-customized tasks. Prior works have achieved notable progress on human-oriented erasing using explicit mask guidance and semantic-aware inpainting. However, they struggle under complex multi-IP scenarios involving human-human occlusions, human-object entanglements, and background interferences. These challenges are mainly due to: 1) Dataset limitations, as existing datasets rarely...
articles.author: Jinghan Yu, Zhiyuan Ma, Yue Ma, Kaiqi Liu, Yuhan Wang, Jianjun Li
articles.content: arXiv:2508.06543v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Recent years have witnessed the success of diffusion models in image-customized tasks. Prior works have achieved notable progress on human-oriented erasing using explicit mask guidance and semantic-aware inpainting. However, they struggle under complex multi-IP scenarios involving human-human occlusions, human-object entanglements, and background interferences. These challenges are mainly due to: 1) Dataset limitations, as existing datasets rarely...

articles.title: OpenHAIV: A Framework Towards Practical Open-World Learning
articles.description: arXiv:2508.07270v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: Substantial progress has been made in various techniques for open-world recognition. Out-of-distribution (OOD) detection methods can effectively distinguish between known and unknown classes in the data, while incremental learning enables continuous model knowledge updates. However, in open-world scenarios, these approaches still face limitations. Relying solely on OOD detection does not facilitate knowledge updates in the model, and incremental...
articles.author: Xiang Xiang, Qinhao Zhou, Zhuo Xu, Jing Ma, Jiaxin Dai, Yifan Liang, Hanlin Li
articles.content: arXiv:2508.07270v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: Substantial progress has been made in various techniques for open-world recognition. Out-of-distribution (OOD) detection methods can effectively distinguish between known and unknown classes in the data, while incremental learning enables continuous model knowledge updates. However, in open-world scenarios, these approaches still face limitations. Relying solely on OOD detection does not facilitate knowledge updates in the model, and incremental...

articles.title: FairDRL-ST: Disentangled Representation Learning for Fair Spatio-Temporal Mobility Prediction
articles.description: arXiv:2508.07518v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: As deep spatio-temporal neural networks are increasingly utilised in urban computing contexts, the deployment of such methods can have a direct impact on users of critical urban infrastructure, such as public transport, emergency services, and traffic management systems. While many spatio-temporal methods focus on improving accuracy, fairness has recently gained attention due to growing evidence that biased predictions in spatio-temporal...

articles.title: BigTokDetect: A Clinically-Informed Vision-Language Model Framework for Detecting Pro-Bigorexia Videos on TikTok
articles.description: arXiv:2508.06515v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Social media platforms increasingly struggle to detect harmful content that promotes muscle dysmorphic behaviors, particularly pro-bigorexia content that disproportionately affects adolescent males. Unlike traditional eating disorder detection focused on the "thin ideal," pro-bigorexia material masquerades as legitimate fitness content through complex multimodal combinations of visual displays, coded language, and motivational messaging that evade...
